title: Obamas to fly to Tucson for memorial service
Latest reaction to Arizona shootings
text: Turn autoplay off Turn autoplay on Please activate cookies in order to turn autoplay off 3.10pm GMT / 10.10am ET: Hello. It is another big day tracking the fallout from the Tucson mass shooting and near fatal wounding of congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords. The country is still coming to terms with the aftermath of the massacre as it prepares for funerals and memorials. Yet the political ramifications are only just beginning. Here are some of the main highlights and developments we will be tracking: • Barack Obama lands in Tucson today to give what is being billed as one of the most important speeches of his presidency so far. Some experts are saying it is an "Oklahoma City moment" after Bill Clinton performed superbly as "mourner in chief" after the Oklahoma City bombing by Timothy McVeigh. ABC news speculates Obama's speech tonight will focus on the victims and avoid politics in a bid to bring the nation together. It also reveals Obama worked through much of last night writing it. • Sarah Palin is still a key part of the story. When is she not? She has released a video message directly taking on her critics who have blamed her – and other senior conservative figures – for inflaming emotions in American politics. Though, typically, she does not exactly use calm language in her message of peace and unity. She says those in the media blaming her are causing a "blood libel" on her reputation. Hmmm. I thought that phrase was generally used to explain the world's long history of brutal and awful antisemitism by those who falsely blame Jews for killing children for their blood – not for slamming a former governor of Alaska and current reality TV star for falsely hinting the American president might be a revolutionary Marxist. • America is also digesting the first and only statement so far to come from the family of alleged shooter Jared Lee Loughner. It was issued last night to journalists essentially besieging the family in their Tucson home. It was brief and deeply apologetic. It is difficult to know what to make of it. It is hard to imagine what that family is going through. But at the same time the American public is demanding some form of explanation of Loughner's background. People want to understand his behaviour on some level. The family's plea for their privacy to be respected is unlikely to be obeyed. • As Arizona prepares for a slew of funerals and memorials, politicians in the state have proved that they actually can work together and pass a decent law when they really want to. In response to news that the disgustingly perverse Westboro Baptist Church was planning an anti-gay, anti-Catholic (anti-everything?) protest at the funeral of a nine-year-old victim of the tragedy, the Arizona legislature passed a law banning protests from near such events. Now, with that done, everyone should just ignore Westboro. They thrive on any sort of confrontation and counter-protest. At the same time, perhaps Arizona politicians can use their new spirit of co-operation to tackle thorny issues like immigration reform in a sensible and comradely atmosphere? Or, more likely, they can now go back to shouting at each other pointlessly. 3.27pm GMT / 10.27am ET: I think this can be filed under Not Very Helpful. But it has emerged that – as the nation sought answers to the Tucson tragedy and reflected upon how easy it was to buy guns – one Arizona politician decided to come to work armed. Or, as state senator Lori Klein so calmly put it: "I pack." That's heat she's packing, not a suitcase. To be exact, Klein decided that Monday was the perfect day to bring her .38 Special to work in her purse. "It goes wherever I go ... I got sworn in with it. I didn't think it was an issue," Klein said, according to the Arizona Republic. It is hard to know where to begin with this particular staggering piece of idiocy. Of course, many will claim Klein – who is a Republican – was taking a sensible precaution at a dangerous time. But most will wonder when meaningful gun control can possibly begin when politicians take such decisions and start speaking like they are Hollywood action heroines. And, given that someone as clearly mentally unstable as Loughner was able to legally buy powerful guns, can we agree we do need to start somewhere? 3.41pm GMT / 10.41am ET: As has often been mentioned, the aftermath of shooting tragedies in the US seems to have developed a ritual all of its own. A great part of this is the ceremonies of mourning and tributes to those who have died or have been gravely wounded. The Tucson shooting stands out, obviously, for striking at the heart of one of the key pillars of American government. It is not stunned office workers mourning their colleagues or traumatised students wondering at the actions of another college shooter, but America's political class itself that feels under attack. So today the House of Representatives – of which Gabrielle Giffords was a member – is passing a resolution on the tragedy. The resolution honours all those slain on Saturday and acknowledges that Giffords was the target. Members of the house will speak for much of today in personal tributes and reflections on what the shooting means. Sometimes – in fact, nearly all the time – it is easy to be cynical at the posturings of most members of Congress. But here, watching the tributes on CNN, it is worth remembering that this time the politicians know Giffords and her staff as friends and work colleagues. 4.39pm GMT / 11.39am EST: The internet has invaded every aspect of modern life and we now leave online traces virtually wherever we go. Usually they have no significance. But in the aftermath of tragedies like that in Tucson suddenly they can provide – with hindsight – vital clues to the mindset of the alleged gunman. It used to be that mass shooters might leave a journal or a final note. Now we have a lifetime's online musings to speculate over, preserved on the internet. The Wall Street Journal has added to the trove of postings already found on YouTube and a UFO conspiracy website by digging up some of Loughner's contributions to a gaming website. They are fascinating stuff. They paint a picture of a young man dealing with mental problems. "Does anyone have aggression 24/7?" he asks the online community. And then ... If you went to prison right now ... What would you be thinking? Elsewhere in the cache of 131 postings Loughner also reveals that he struggled to find a job and felt bad after being rejected by women. More prosaically, he also talks about diets and weight-lifting. Other postings were typical of the rambling nonsensical style that Loughner exhibited on other websites and talk about grammar and conspiracy theories. There is no smoking gun here – he does not mention Giffords or indeed anything very political – but they do offer a chilling insight into Loughner's state of mind. 5.17pm GMT / 12.17pm ET: The defence of conservatives to the accusation that they have been inflaming debate in American politics runs to two basic arguments. The first one can be summed up: it's a lie put out by by the liberal media. The second one can be summed up: liberals do it too! A nice corrective to these arguments has been assembled by the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence. They have come up with a timeline of the last few years that shows some of the more shocking incidents of rightwing violence and hysterical imagery. It shows that diehard conservatives do indulge in this and on a scale that those wacky liberals just cannot match. Some of it seems a little unfair. It is probably not right to pin the actions of a single crazed Neo-Nazi on the whole rightwing in general or even the extreme fringe of the right wing. But some of the comments from mainstream Republicans, radio talk show hosts and Tea Party figures are worth remembering. A few "highlights" (there are many, many more): 11 March 2009: NRA CEO Wayne LaPierre speaks at the 2009 Conservative Political Action Conference and announces that "our founding fathers understood that the guys with the guns make the rules". 31 July 2009: On WWJB-AM in Hernando County, Bob Haa tells a listener not to waste his ammunition on targets, to save it for the administration. Haa is later visited by an agent for the secret service. 25 August 2009: During a barbecue in Twin Falls, Idaho, an audience member asks Rex Rammell, a candidate in the 2010 Idaho Republican primary, a question about "Obama tags" during a discussion about state-issued tags for wolf hunting. Rammell responds: "The Obama tags? We'd buy some of those." 26 August 2009: At a rally in Texas, gubernatorial candidate and Tea Party favourite Debra Medina states: "We understand that the tree of freedom is occasionally watered with the blood of tyrants and patriots." 5.28pm GMT / 12.28pm ET: My colleague Stephen Bates has written a piece explaining more about the term "blood libel", which Sarah Palin used in her video message today (see 3.10pm GMT / 10.10am ET). Stephen writes: Sarah Palin's use of the phrase "blood libel" could scarcely be more incendiary, especially in a religious country like the US. The blood libel refers specifically to perhaps the most notorious verse in the Bible: Matthew 27:25, which has been used by some Christians to persecute Jews for nearly 2,000 years. That it should be used by an avowedly Christian politician about a Jewish one just takes crassness and insensitivity to a new level. One can only hope that Palin, or her advisers, did not appreciate the context, or the history. The verse in Matthew refers to the scene during Christ's trial before Pontius Pilate, before his execution, where the Roman governor, not being able to find fault with the accused man, publicly washed his hands of his fate, saying the crowd bore responsibility for his death. The Gospel says the crowd shouted back: "His blood be on us and on our children," a phrase taken by Christians for centuries to indicate that the Jewish people as a whole and for perpetuity bore direct responsibility for the crucifixion and were therefore fair game for persecution and extermination. It has been used to justify pogroms, expulsions and discrimination and has fed Christian myths, such as those circulating in the middle ages, that Jews kidnapped and sacrificed Christian children to use their blood during Passover commemorations. 5.33pm GMT / 12.33pm ET: Following the antics of the Westboro Baptist Church reminds me of that old saying about not wrestling with a pig: you both end up covered in mud, but the pig likes it. However, these latest developments need a little discussion. First the good news: the church will no longer picket the funeral of nine-year-old victim Christina Taylor Green. Hurray! Now the bad news: they are doing that in return for media interviews that will grant them airtime in Toronto and Phoenix. Also the bad news part two: they are going to picket the funeral of slain judge John Roll instead. Oh, and also the site of the shooting itself. Staggering really. But Guardian commenter "blearyboy" below has also helpfully pointed out an interesting post analysing Westboro from the point of view of a money-making legal scam. It makes a good read. For what it's worth: I don't think the money-making scam side of things and the insane religious cult side of things necessarily cancel each other out. 5.51pm GMT / 12.51 ET: It is a funny old job being president. Not only do you have the tricky task of running the world's only superpower on a daily basis, but – because the president combines the jobs of prime minister and head of state – you also become the symbolic face of the nation. In times like these this involves the media giving you the temporary title of "mourner in chief". Most presidents wear this hat at some stage of their time in office. George W Bush had it after the 9/11 attacks. Bill Clinton put it on in the wake of the Oklahoma City bombing. Ronald Reagan did a typically emotional job in the wake of the Challenger space-shuttle disaster. Now it is Barack Obama's turn with his Tucson speech. This CNN analysis does a good job of covering the basics of this role. But to me this seems a little overblown compared to the scale of previous tragedies. That is not to downplay what happened in Tucson. But the alleged actions of a madman do not really seem to match a spacecraft exploding on launch or a bomb that killed scores of people in the heartland or a terrorist attack that came to define our modern era. Still, it is going to be test of Obama's skills and political instincts to see how he handles this. Will we see "campaign Obama" who inspired the crowds with his emphatic gifts? Or "governing Obama" who has become increasingly isolated from the public mood of both left and right and become kind of a cold fish? 6.29pm GMT / 1.29pm ET: Sadhbh Walshe writes The Right Word on Comment is free, a series of articles tracking what conservative TV and radio hosts are saying. She has written an extensive piece explaining the reactions of Bill O'Reilly, Rush Limbaugh and Glenn Beck to the Arizona shootings. 6.36pm GMT / 1.36am ET: Sarah Palin's use of the word "blood libel" is now starting to genuinely dominate the news agenda. That simple two word phrase – so loaded with dreadful history and meaning – has elevated her statement from what should have been a sidebar or brief mention in the day's events to a global story. She is burning up Twitter and the BBC briefly put her as the lead story on its website, ahead of Barack Obama's coming Tucson speech. Which leaves a key question: did she mean it? Did Palin use the words "blood libel" knowing that she would inject herself front and centre into the story, overshadowing the president and filling a meme on the right that she is a victim of a vast leftwing media conspiracy? Or did she just unknowingly pick it up? On that latter point the words have been knocking around the conservative media in recent days. The Wall Street Journal ran a piece two days ago attacking those playing the blame game with the headline: "The Arizona Tragedy and the Politics of Blood Libel". The Washington Examiner on the same day hit out at New York Times's columnist Paul Krugman for "the blood libel of blame". Conservative blogger Andrew Breitbart also used the term blood libel before Palin did. So what happened? Did Palin – who is as wily as they come when it comes to media – consciously want to be part of this debate? Was she dog-whistling the conservative right with a loaded phrase? Or was she just googling around on conservative websites and came across a phrase used by others that she thought fit her situation? 6.56pm GMT / 1.56pm ET: Let's turn away for a moment from the political side of the Tucson tragedy and focus on something a bit more edifying. The truly remarkable thing about the story has been the amazing tale of Gabrielle Giffords' survival. She was shot in the head at point blank range and had a bullet go through the entire left side of her brain. That she is alive is a miracle and a tribute to her surgeons and the paramedics who rushed her to hospital. The latest news from her doctors at the University Medical Centre in Tucson continues to be good. Though she is still critical, Dr Peter Rhee said: "We're at the very edge of the woods." Of course, Giffords faces a long journey back to health and the extent of permanent damage is unknown. But she is alive, breathing and responding to commands. By Friday, Rhee said, she might even start to show signs of recovery as her brain swelling decreases. Here is the latest from the Arizona Republic. 7.17pm / 2.17pm ET: This is sad news. But it has just emerged that alleged gunman Jared Lee Loughner (left) was stopped by the authorities on Saturday morning, before the attack on Gabrielle Giffords, after he ran a red light. He was not stopped by the police but by an officer with Arizona Game and Fish. Loughner was described as "very forthcoming" and "very polite, very subdued" during the chat with the officer. He was issued with a warning, had his car inspected and told to move on. Maybe some will place blame here out of an understandable desire for "what might have been". But that would be a mistake and a use of hindsight that is very out of place. 7.52pm GMT / 2.52pm ET: Here comes Rush Limbaugh (left) to Sarah Palin's rescue. As Palin deals with the fallout from her comments about "blood libel" she perhaps needs someone to take the heat off. Someone, maybe, who could say something so outlandish and awful that it would distract from the storm of criticism heading Palin's way all around the world. Limbaugh has gamely stepped up to the plate. The conservative radio show demi-god, who has the popularity and power to make most Republican leaders kowtow to his whims, took to the airwaves with this analysis claiming Democrats support alleged shooter Jared Lee Loughner: What Mr Loughner knows is that he has the full support of a major political party in this country. He's sitting there in jail. He knows what's going on, he knows that ... the Democrat party is attempting to find anybody but him to blame. He knows if he plays his cards right, he's just a victim. Thanks, El Rushbo. The problem here is that Limbaugh's comments are frequently so outrageous that this likely won't deflect any flak from Palin. The bigger problem, of course, is that Limbaugh is a genuine figure of power in American political life. Statements like these should make him a national laughing stock. But they do not. Millions of listeners tune in and love him every week. This line of attack from Limbaugh also might signal a "no go" to any conservatives who wanted to make dealing with America's mentally ill a part of this debate. He is clearly willing to agressively play up the line that any attempt to understand Loughner as mentally ill is simply putting the criminal on the same footing as the victims. 7.55pm GMT / 2.55pm ET: Here is a gallery of pictures of reaction to the shootings. 8.00pm GMT / 3.00pm ET: My colleague Peter Beaumont has written about Sarah Palin's blood libel comment and concludes it was a massive mis-step that shows she is unable to act the stateswoman and might blow a Tucson-sized hole in any presidential bid. Peter writes: More problematic still is a scenario where Palin knows what "blood libel" actually means, attaching herself as a victim on the same footing as those who suffered centuries of antisemitic persecution that culminated in the Holocaust. Is this what Palin is implying? Poor Sarah. That criticism of her crass political style is of the same order as the pogroms and expulsions perpetrated against the Jewish people? His conclusion: This video statement was a second chance to show how she could act as a statesman and engage with the debate about America's overheated political language at a time when families are still mourning their dead. She had an opportunity to demonstrate that she was not simply a polarising and partisan figure and to dismiss the suspicions that she is self-serving, narcissistic and self-obsessed. In that, Sarah Palin has manifestly failed. And she has failed not just as a politician, but as a human being, too. Read the whole thing here. It is worth it. 8.31pm GMT / 3.31pm ET: My colleague Ed Pilkington in New York has filed a story on the dramatic rise in handgun sales following the shooting. In the days since the tragedy, gun sales have increased dramatically. According to figures obtained from the FBI by Bloomberg, some 263 handguns were sold in Arizona the day after the killings, a rise of 60% on a year ago. Handgun sales were up 65% to 395 in Ohio and nationally increased by about 5% to 7,906. The spike in sales has been particularly pronounced for precisely the model of gun and ammunition deployed by the shooter, Jared Lee Loughner, on Saturday: the Austrian-made Glock 19. The handgun is used by many law enforcement agencies in the US, including the NYPD. 8.45pm GMT / 3.45pm ET: Contrary to rumours on Twitter and elsewhere, Sarah Palin has not taken down her controversial "blood libel" video message. It's still here, linked to from her Facebook page, which also contains a transcript. My colleague Chris McGreal has written about some of the criticisms of Palin's choice of language from Tucson here: The Anti-Defamation League, a group in New York that campaigns against antisemitism, said that while it "was inappropriate at the outset to blame Sarah Palin and others for causing this tragedy", it objected to her language. "We wish that Palin had not invoked the phrase 'blood-libel' in reference to the actions of journalists and pundits in placing blame for the shooting in Tucson on others. while the term has become part of the English parlance to refer to someone being falsely accused, we wish that Palin had used another phrase, instead of one so fraught with pain in Jewish history," it said. Julie Roginsky, a Democratic party strategist, said that she does not blame Palin "for the actions of one deranged gunman". She added: "The term 'blood libel,' however, is a term so loaded with bigotry and historic persecution that it should be consigned to the ash heap of history where the darkest days of antisemitism dwell. Whether she was aware of its historical context is irrelevant. She is a national figure with a huge following and so she should use her words carefully," she wrote in a Politico blog. 8.51pm GMT / 3.51pm ET: Time to swim furiously away from the Sarah Palin "blood libel" debate for a moment. It is a sad state of affairs when a debate about violent rhetoric rapidly descends into a lot of violent rhetoric. Instead check out this story from the Atlantic about the remarkable medical survival of Gabrielle Giffords. It is a bit grim (actually it is a lot grim) but it gives a nuts and bolts description of how Giffords was able to survive what should have been an instantly fatal wound. It is a mixture of luck, medical skill and unusual facts (a bullet in the head can sometimes be better than a blunt force knock due to being "focused"). Who knew? 9.22pm GMT / 4.22pm ET: With the Loughner family keeping their silence apart from a simple statement and plea for privacy, details of the background of suspect Jared Lee Loughner are slow to seep out. However, a picture is beginning to emerge. It is fairly disturbing but one has to be careful with hindsight. He had trouble with friends and college, his family appeared very private and he behaved oddly at an animal shelter. Some neighbours thought the Loughners were very weird, some just mildly eccentric and some thought them normal. This Associated Press story has some good details, but perhaps the most fascinating new fact is that Loughner and his father had an angry dispute on the morning of the shooting. It ended with Loughner running off into the desert after Loughner Sr asked his son why he was taking a black bag out of the car boot. This probably happened after Loughner was stopped and searched that morning by a local Arizona Game and Fish officer for running a red light. People looking for some sort of trigger event might find it here in this father-son spat. Or, much more likely, they might find another narrowly missed opportunity to stop Loughner before he allegedly committed his crime. 9.45pm GMT / 4.45pm ET: After a day in which Barack Obama must have marvelled at Sarah Palin's ability to steal his thunder, it might be time to look ahead to tonight's Tucson memorial service to honour the victims of Saturday's shooting. People have been queuing up since the wee hours of the morning to get access to the McKale Memorial Center on the University of Arizona campus. At least 14,000 are expected to cram inside and tickets are on a first-come-first-served basis. Some 500 press requests were received by the college. The service is called "Together We Thrive: Tucson and America" and that is likely to set the tone for Obama's much anticipated speech, which is expected to come in at a brief 15 minutes. Other events for the service include a Native American blessing, some music and speeches by other political leaders such as Arizona's Republican governor Jan Brewer and attorney general Eric Holder. A schedule can be found here. 10.14pm GMT / 5.14pm ET: Not quite sure why these comments have not gained any traction, but US secretary of state Hillary Clinton (left) has called Jared Lee Loughner an "extremist" who acted out his "political views" in some ways. Clinton was talking to CNN and these comments seem to go a little above and beyond what most people in the centre and on the left are saying. That argument tends to be that Loughner allegedly carried out the shooting in Tucson because he was mentally ill but that he may have acted against a general background of unpleasent and violent rhetoric in public life. That seems almost common sense but Clinton's comments seem to take that a step further. The key quote: Based on what I know, this is a criminal defendant who was in some ways motivated by his own political views, who had a particular animus toward the congresswoman and I think when you cross the line from expressing opinions that are of conflicting differences in our political environment into taking action that's violent action, that's a hallmark of extremism, whether it comes from the right, the left, from al-Qaida, from anarchists, whoever it is. That is a form of extremism. 10.27pm GMT / 5.27pm ET: It has been a remarkable day of activity so far in tracking the coverage of the Tucson shooting of congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords and others and it is not yet over. Here are the key developments: • The nation is waiting for the official memorial service in Tucson during which Barack Obama will give a short speech to the American public. The moment represents a chance for Obama to act as "mourner-in-chief" and call for unity. He is unlikely to make any overtly political statement and instead keep it personal and respectful. US secretary of state Hillary Clinton has called Jared Lee Loughner an "extremist" who acted out his "political views" in some ways (see 10.14pm GMT / 5.14pm ET). • Few things seem to happen in American political life that do not somehow involve Sarah Palin. The former Alaska governor caused a global outcry by claiming that media attacks on her for inflaming opinion against Giffords and other Americans amounted to a "blood libel". Palin made the claim in a video posted to Facebook and instantly shot to the top of the news programmes, eclipsing Obama and virtually every other development. • Giffords herself continues to do well in hospital. Or, more accurately, as well as can be expected for someone suffering from such a traumatic brain injury. Her doctors continue to be pleased with her progress though her long-term prognosis is still up in the air, in terms of how complete her recovery will be. But it seems there will be a recovery of some sort, which is nothing short of remarkable. • More details continued to emerge about the alleged shooter Jared Lee Loughner. Most poignantly two apparent incidents on Saturday morning could perhaps have alerted people that something was wrong but sadly were missed. Firstly, Loughner was stopped and cautioned after running a red light. But then he was allowed to go on his way. Secondly, he had a row with his father and ran off after Loughner Sr challenged him about a mysterious bag he was removing from the family car's boot. I will be taking a break now but will return at around 1am GMT / 8pm ET for live coverage of the Tucson memorial service and Obama's speech. 00.53am GMT / 7.53pm ET: America awaits the beginning of the memorial service in Tucson, Arizona, for all the victims of Saturday's shootings. Of course, the focus is on President Barack Obama and the speech he is set to give. Comparisons are being made to other "mourner-in-chief" moments of previous presidents, such as Bill Clinton after the Oklahoma City bombing and Ronald Reagan after the Challenger space shuttle disaster. It is no easy task. But he should be able to rise to the occasion. Certainly, he won't be mentioning "blood libels", à la Sarah Palin (I hope). Obama has also visited the wounded Gabrielle Giffords in hospital. "The president wanted to begin this solemn trip by stopping first at the hospital where Congresswoman Giffords and others continue to recuperate," a White House official told the New York Times. Meanwhile, my colleague Chris McGreal is on the ground and files these thoughts from the service in Tucson. Demand for the 14,000 seats in the sports arena where Obama is to speak is so large that the authorities were already directing people to a nearby stadium before the first of the mourners were seated. Many of those in the arena are students who waited in the winter sun for hours. The mourners, if that's what they can be called as many said they were principally there to see the president, gave a standing ovation and cheers for two of the surgeons who have been treating the wounded congresswoman. 1.09am GMT / 8.09pm ET: This seems worth noting: CNN makes a valuable contribution to the history of Jared Lee Loughner by getting a definitive response from the police on their prior contacts with the alleged shooter. Says Pima County Sheriff's bureau chief Richard Kastigar: The events that led up to what happened Saturday as they relate to law enforcement contact really do not add up in their totality to anything that would cause a police officer to say. 'This guy is going to go out there and shoot 20 people.' There's nothing there. It seems like a line that is aimed at putting a swift end to any conspiracy theories out there about just how much contact law enforcement had with Loughner. Given the state of debate in America at the moment, that is a good idea. Kastigar tells the channel that they absolutely did not have enough information or contact with Loughner to have any idea of what he was planning. "I couldn't underscore that more," Kastigar said. Of course, there could be an element of spinning that line to deflect criticism of the police, but – unless someone comes up with hard facts about some new incident – it seems fair enough. Loughner drank, smoked pot and acted weird. Weirder than most, in fact. But it is impossible to say that it was obvious he would do what he allegedly did. 1.13am GMT / 8.13pm EST: President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama have entered. They are shaking hands to loud cheers. Which is a little bit like a campaign event. Not their fault. But a little odd for the beginning of a memorial. Obama is looking down, appearing sombre, with his hands clasped in front of him. Then the music stops and things get serious and quiet pretty quickly for the crowd. 1.15am GMT / 8.15pm ET: Carlos Gonzales, half-Native American and half-Mexican, resident of Tucson, gives a traditional blessing. It was a slightly bizarre ritual, but one done with a dose of humanity. "Let us work towards harmony," he said, striking a tone that Obama will likely follow. Obama, though, probably will not carry as big a sacred feather. Gonzales went on to speak of families and the need to honour them. "Let us use humour when appropriate for humour is healing and can help people," he said. I have to say: I agree. After this day of "blood libel" and "blood libel" reaction, we could all do with a bit of that. 1.26am GMT / 8.26pm ET: Not surprisingly, the early bits of the service are all about Tucson. Native American Carlos Gonzales gave a shoutout to local civic pride, and now University of Arizona Robert Shelton is using his platform to praise his town. "It is, in the truest sense of the word, a community. We know each other and we care about each other," he said. Every city where a tragedy occurs that attracts the global media gets tarred with the horror of the event – it is reasonable to point out all the other things about a place. Things that define it far more than one random tragedy. Shelton's sentiment likely explains all the cheers from the local crowd. 1.42am GMT / 8.42pm ET: Daniel Hernandez, Gabrielle Giffords' student intern who is credited with helping save her life, gives an amazing and touching speech. He calls for unity and pays tribute to Giffords and the other victims. He rejects the use of the word "hero", and instead, praises those who lost their lives, as well as Giffords herself, her doctors and other public servants. It was a remarkably assured speech, with a nice balance of humility and respect. Huge cheers. Then Arizona's Republican Governor Jan Brewer takes the stage. She looks less calm and assured than Hernandez, to be honest, but she has never been a natural public speaker in the media spotlight. She strikes an entirely nonpartisan tone – surely setting the stage for the other political figures who will come after her. "I know this, though, Arizona is united in a mission of recovery," she says, calling the shooting "one mad man's act of darkness". 1.46am GMT / 8.46pm ET: Janet Napolitano – a former Democratic Arizona governor and current head of the Department of Homeland Security – reached for comfort from the Bible during her brief speech. "The violence that occurred Saturday does not represent this community, this state or this country," she said, before adding that words can fail people at such times. Then, she read a passage from the Old Testament. That is a sure way to keep things apolitical, not least because it is hard instantly to understand the meaning of the piece of scripture. US Attorney General Eric Holder was next up. He, too, read from the Bible (the New Testament, this time). It's good strategy and a reminder that this is a memorial. 1.53am GMT / 8.53pm ET: President Barack Obama is on the stage. He gets huge cheers but maintains a stony expression throughout. This is his "mourner-in-chief" moment. His first words are about the families of the victims. "I have come here tonight as an American who like all Americans kneels to pray with you today and will stand by you tomorrow," he says: There is nothing I can say that fill the sudden hole torn in your heart. Then, he, too, like Holder and Napolitano, starts to read from scripture. 1.57am GMT / 8.57pm ET: Obama then praises Giffords for her openness in holding public meetings like that in which she was engaged at the time she was shot. He calls it a "quintessentially American scene" of open democracy and civic engagement. He pays tribute to slain Judge John Roll, which is proper. Giffords may be the focus and has suffered terribly, but she is alive. Roll, and five others, are dead. Obama moves on to talk of the other slain victims and tell brief stories of their lives. He is speaking well. Though one would expect that from a gifted orator. 2.01am GMT / 9.01pm ET: Obama completes his pen portraits of the dead victims. It was a nice part of the speech, laced with well-placed touches of humour (perhaps the president picked that up from Carlos Gonzales). That felt right. The nation is in mourning, but just as Tucson should not be defined by a tragedy, nor should these victims be defined by the random, awful nature of their death. They were much more than that. A little bit of celebration is good among the mourners. Then, Obama springs a surprise. He has visited Gabrielle Giffords in hospital and brings this good news. Gaby opened her eyes for the first time. She knows we are here, she knows we love her, she knows we are rooting for her. Huge cheers. Not surprisingly. Hard not to smile at that. Obama seems to be in his element. He may even have departed from the script and gone with the mood of the event here. 2.12am GMT / 9.12pm ET: Obama is actually smiling now, as he pays tribute to the heroes of the day. That feels unexpected but also appropriate. Why not celebrate brave deeds? He is clapping from the podium. So much for recent received wisdom about Obama's apparent inability to connect with ordinary people and "feel their pain", as Bill Clinton used to. Heroism is found not only on the fields of battle … heroism is here in the hearts of so many of our fellow citizens, all around us just waiting to be summoned. Finally, he is tackling the meat of the issue: what now for America? "How can we be true to their memory?" he asks. He talks about the "national conversation" that has surrounded the issue, from "gun safety" (note: he did not say "regulation"!) to mental illness laws. "It is important for us to pause for a moment and make sure we are talking with each other in way that heals, and not in a way that wounds," he says, taking on the thorny issue of political polarisation. No "blood libels" for Obama, then. And, like every other Democratic speaker tonight, he turns to the Bible and quotes from the Book of Job. What we cannot do is use this tragedy as one more occasion to turn on each other. That we cannot do. Let's use this occasion to expand our moral imaginations. And he asks for people to listen to each other. This is the key message: tone it down, America, he is saying. At the same time, he is practising what he is preaching. There will be no blame game from Obama. 2.20am GMT / 9.20pm ET: Obama is turning on the emotions now. "What matters is not wealth or power or status or fame, but how well we have loved," he says. That sounds – to my cynical ears – a little too much like a line from a Hollywood movie. He then compounds it by talking of "an American family 300 million strong". But it's basically good stuff and impossible to argue with the sentiment. At the moment, it is is hard to see anyone disagreeing with this speech. The vast majority of pundits, I think, will greatly praise it. Emotional, non-political, but taking on the core issues without indulging in finger-pointing himself. Obama says a debate should happen about these events, but that it should be conducted better: "Let's make sure it's worthy of those we have lost." If anyone is comparing Obama and Palin over who has reacted more presidentially (though they really shouldn't be doing that), then Obama has shown Palin how it's really done. We may not be able to stop all evil in the world, but I know that how we treat one another, that is entirely up to us. 2.24am GMT / 9.24pm ET: He nears the end with a rousing call. For the first time, his voice rises, almost in anger, as he talks of nine-year-old victim Christina Taylor Green, and demands America lives up to her memory and the expectations of children like her. The crowd – according to the New York Times, more than 14,000-strong – goes wild; he pauses to absorb the cheers. That was quite a moment. He ends with the words: "May God bless and keep those we have lost in eternal peace. May he watch over the survivors and may he bless the United States of America." The remarks lasted 34 minutes, which was much longer than expected. 2.47am GMT / 9.47pm ET: So that was that. My feeling is that Obama did well. He was probably always going to be fine and the hurdles in front of him were not hard to jump. But his mixture of sombre speech, Bible-quoting, humorous anecdote and, finally, bipartisan hectoring was impressive. He even managed to stun everyone by revealing that Giffords has now opened her eyes during his visit to the hospital. That was an impressive, almost miraculous touch. On the cable news channels, the reaction seems to agree. David Gergen on CNN said: "What the president had to say at the end of his speech was important … that resonated with the audience, and I am sure it will resonate with the rest of the country." Over on Fox News, Brett Hume said: "It was a very powerful speech." Now, we wait to read the morning newspapers and get their more considered reaction. Until then, good night.

title: Obama visits wounded Arizona congresswoman in hospital
text:
GET BREAKING NEWS IN YOUR BROWSER. CLICK HERE TO TURN ON NOTIFICATIONS. X OUR PICKS: TUCSON, Ariz. — Summoning the soul of a nation, President Barack Obama on Wednesday implored Americans to honor those slain and injured in the Arizona shootings by becoming better people, telling a polarized citizenry that it is time to talk with each other “in a way that heals, not in a way that wounds.” Following a hospital bedside visit with Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, the target of the assassination, he said: “She knows we’re here, and she knows we love her.” In an electrifying moment, the president revealed that Giffords, who on Saturday was shot point-blank in the head, had opened her eyes for the first time shortly after his hospital visit. First lady Michelle Obama held hands with Giffords’ husband, Mark Kelly, as the news brought soaring cheers from thousands gathered for a memorial service. Obama bluntly conceded that there is no way to know what triggered the shooting rampage that left six people dead, 13 others wounded and the nation shaken. He tried instead to leave indelible memories of the people who were gunned down, and to rally the country to use the moment as a reflection on the nation’s behavior and compassion. “I believe we can be better,” Obama said to a capacity crowd in the university’s basketball arena and to countless others watching around the country. “Those who died here, those who saved lives here — they help me believe,” the president said. “We may not be able to stop all evil in the world, but I know that how we treat one another is entirely up to us.” In crafting his comments, Obama clearly sought a turning point in the raw debate that has defined national politics. He faced the expectations to do more than console, but to encourage a new day of civility, all without getting overly political in a memorial service. Obama settled on a theme of challenging the country to have a debate that is worthy of those who died. He tapped into the raging debate about the role of incendiary rhetoric without dwelling on it. “Let’s remember that it is not because a simple lack of civility caused this tragedy. It did not,” the president said. After offering personal accounts of every person who died, he challenged anyone listening to think of how to honor their memories, and he was not shy about offering direction. He admonished against any instinct to point blame or to drift into political pettiness or to latch onto simple explanations that may have no merit. The president said it was OK, even essential, for the country to suddenly be debating gun control, mental health services and the motivations of the killer. But then he added: “At a time when our discourse has become so sharply polarized — at a time when we are far too eager to lay the blame for all that ails the world at the feet of those who think differently than we do — it’s important for us to pause for a moment and make sure that we are talking with each other in a way that heals, not a way that wounds,” the president said. The shooting happened as Giffords, a three-term Democrat who represents southern Arizona, was holding a community outreach event in a Tucson shopping center parking lot Saturday. A gunman shot her in the head and worked his way down the line of people waiting to talk with her, law enforcement officials said. The attack ended when bystanders tackled the man, Jared Lee Loughner, 22, who is in custody. Obama’s speech, by turns somber and hopeful, at times took on the tone of an exuberant pep rally as he heralded the men who wrestled the gunman to the ground, the woman who grabbed the shooter’s ammunition, the doctors and nurses who treated the injured, the intern who rushed to Giffords’ aid. The crowd erupted in multiple standing ovations as each was singled out for praise. The president ended up speaking for more than half an hour, doubling the expected length of his comments. Memories of the six people killed dominated much of Obama’s speech. The president, for example, recalled how federal Judge John Roll was on his way from attending Mass when he stopped to say hello to Giffords and was gunned down; Dorothy Morris, shielded by her husband, but killed nonetheless; and Phyllis Schneck, a Republican who took a shine to Giffords, a Democrat, and wanted to know her better. He spoke at length of 9-year-old Christina Taylor Green, the only girl on her Little League team, who often said she wanted to be the first woman to play in the major leagues. She had just been elected to the student council at her elementary school and had an emerging interest in public service. “I want us to live up to her expectations. I want our democracy to be as good as she imagined it,” Obama said. The little girl was born on Sept. 11, 2001, and had been featured in a book about 50 babies born that day. The inscriptions near her photo spoke of wishes for a happy child’s life, including splashing in puddles. Said Obama: “If there are rain puddles in heaven, Christina is jumping in them today.” Obama hit an emotional high point when he told of Giffords opening her eyes for the first time not long after his visit to her bedside. “Gabby opened her eyes, so I can tell you: She knows we are here, she knows we love her, and she knows that we are rooting for her through what is undoubtedly going to be a difficult journey,” Obama said. The lawmakers who were in Giffords’ hospital room when she opened her eyes were three of her close female friends in Congress: House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi of California, Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, D-Fla., and Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-N.Y. “The doctors couldn’t believe it,” Wasserman Schultz later told CNN. “It was the most incredible experience that I have ever had.” Giffords is expected to survive, although her condition and the extent of her recovery remain in doubt. As finger-pointing emerged in Washington and beyond over whether harsh political rhetoric played a role in creating motivation for the attack, Obama sought to calm the rhetoric. “Bad things happen,” he said, “and we must guard against simple explanations in the aftermath.” He spoke of decency and goodness, declaring: “The forces that divide us are not as strong as those that unite us.” Obama’s appeal for civility played out against a deepening political debate. Earlier in the day, Republican Sarah Palin, criticized by some for marking Giffords’ district with the crosshairs of a gun sight during last fall’s campaign, had taken to Facebook to accuse pundits and journalists of using the attack to incite hatred and violence. Obama spoke to a crowd of more than 13,000 in the arena and thousands more listened on from an overflow area in the football stadium. About a mile away, at University Medical Center, Giffords lay fighting for her life. Other victims also remained there hospitalized. The memorial service was an important part of the mourning process for some of those who had lined up hours in advance to gain a seat. “If we don’t say goodbye and have a chance to say goodbye in an appropriate way, it will linger,” said Patty Sirls, 62. “So, for me, it’s a closure.” Sign up for Newsletters and Alerts As you comment, please be respectful of other commenters and other viewpoints. Our goal with article comments is to provide a space for civil, informative and constructive conversations. 			here.

title: President counsels against 'pointing fingers,' urges unity
text: Philip Rucker, Anne E. Kornblut and Danna Hedgpeth / Washington Post TUCSON, Ariz. -- President Barack Obama comforted a community suffused with grief and summoned the nation to recommit to a more civil public discourse as he delivered a eulogy Wednesday evening urging Americans to talk with each other "in a way that heals, not in a way that wounds." Evoking memories of the six people killed here Saturday, Obama seized on the mass shooting at a congresswoman's supermarket meet-and-greet to tackle directly the subject of the nation's harsh political dialogue. He sharply decried the "politics and point-scoring and pettiness that drifts away with the next news cycle." "Rather than pointing fingers or assigning blame, let us use this occasion to expand our moral imaginations, to listen to each other more carefully, to sharpen our instincts for empathy, and remind ourselves of all the ways our hopes and dreams are bound together," Obama told 14,000 people at the University of Arizona's McKale Memorial Center. Obama did not ascribe a political motive to the shooter, Jared Lee Loughner, or suggest that either party was to blame. Rather, in a 33-minute speech, he sought to move the nation past the tragedy. Obama paid a surprise visit to victims recovering at University Medical Center, including Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, the Arizona Democrat, whom he visited for nine minutes in the intensive care unit. "Gabby opened her eyes and I can tell you she knows we are here, she knows we love her, and she knows we are rooting for her," Obama said. In Washington, lawmakers still unnerved by the assassination attempt on one of their own offered a display of bipartisan unity. More than 120 Democrats and Republicans went to the well of the House to pay tribute in moving and sometimes tearful speeches. The House unanimously approved a resolution late Wednesday condemning the attack and praising citizen and emergency responders. Ohio members of Congress -- including Democrats Dennis Kucinich of Cleveland and Marcia Fudge of Warrensville Heights, as well as Dayton-area GOP Rep. Mike Turner -- took to the House floor to wish Giffords well and decry violence. "Our hearts are broken, but our spirit is not," House Speaker John Boehner of Ohio said. "This is a time for the House to lock arms, in prayer for those fallen and wounded, and in resolve to carry on the dialogue of democracy." "In the sweep of history, this attack was an attack on liberty," added Toledo Democratic Rep. Marcy Kaptur. "It desecrates our worth as a people. We must all search our souls. How could such a heinous act transpire?" Judge Larry Burns of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California was appointed to hear Loughner's case after federal judges in Arizona removed themselves. Meanwhile, in an eight-minute video posted online, Sarah Palin fiercely dismissed any notion that her firearms-infused political attacks contributed to Giffords' shooting. Palin also launched a controversy by accusing her critics of mounting a "blood libel" against her, a reference denounced as offensive by Jewish groups. title: Loughner's Smirk Behind Bars
Loughner could have been committed under Arizona law
text: Arizona makes it easier than most states to commit mentally ill people to psychiatric care, even against their will. But that doesn't mean that everyone gets the help they need. "The state laws are some of the best in the country," said Jack Potts, a forensic psychiatrist in Phoenix. "The follow-up is not." Under Arizona law, anyone can call the county or regional health authorities with concerns about a person's mental health, and authorities are required to send out mobile units to assess the person's condition, said Brian Stettin, policy director at the Treatment Advocacy Center in Arlington, Va., which advocates for involuntary commitment for mental illness. The person who files a request for commitment must list the names of two witnesses who can attest to the subject's behavior, although they don't have to sign the document themselves, Potts said. REPORTS: Loughner had 'dark personality' POLL: Conservatives not to blame for Ariz. shooting Typically, states allow involuntary commitment only if people pose a danger to themselves or others, or if they are profoundly disabled by their mental illness, to the point of being unable to take care of themselves, said Paul Ragan, associate professor of psychiatry at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine in Nashville. But Arizona allows for involuntary commitment if someone is deteriorating from a mental illness and could benefit from treatment, Potts said. The law is intended to catch people before they do something dangerous. He said he knows of a high school principal, for example, who requested a mental health evaluation for an unstable student. The law also provides up to 90 days of inpatient hospital treatment, Potts said. A judge can order a patient to take his medication; patients who refuse can be sent back to the hospital. Yet Arizona often lacks the resources to treat people, he said. The state has one of the lowest ratios in the country for inpatient psychiatric beds for its population size. Across the USA, budget cuts have forced hospitals to close 4,000 inpatient psychiatric beds since 2009 — leaving them less able to take in the mentally ill, said Michael Fitzpatrick, executive director of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI). Arizona has eliminated hundreds of positions for mental health case workers, who help coordinate patients' care, Fitzpatrick said. In a national score card rating the accessibility of mental health services, the alliance in 2009 gave Arizona a C, "which is pretty close to a failing grade," said psychiatrist Anand Pandya of Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles; 21 states scored a D, and none earned an A. To create the score card, the alliance had volunteers in each state try to schedule an appointment with a mental health professional. "It's very hard to get an appointment with a psychiatrist in Arizona," Pandya said. "Pretty much across the board, it takes a lot of time. There's no one clear number to call, and it's hard to figure out where to go from their website, even if you are completely mentally competent. The services in Arizona just aren't designed to be readily accessible." PARENTS: Mental health lessons from the Tucson tragedy Arizona state officials, for example, were unable to tell NAMI how many patients they actually serve, according to the report. Arizona residents who spoke to NAMI for the report said they had many problems getting care, facing six- to eight-week waits to see a psychiatrist. Others complained of overworked case workers with nearly 100 clients. One unnamed patient quoted in the report told NAMI, "When I first tried to get help after attempting suicide, I was told that I wasn't sick enough to qualify."

title: Due To Arizona Conflicts, California Judge Takes Over Loughner Case

Obama: In wake of tragic shooting, let's shelve blame and embrace civility
text:
GET BREAKING NEWS IN YOUR BROWSER. CLICK HERE TO TURN ON NOTIFICATIONS. X OUR PICKS: TUCSON, Ariz. — President Barack Obama comforted a community suffused with grief and summoned the nation to recommit to a more civil public discourse as he delivered a eulogy Wednesday evening urging Americans to talk with each other “in a way that heals, not in a way that wounds.” Evoking memories of the six killed Saturday in Tucson, Obama seized upon the mass shooting at a congresswoman’s supermarket meet-and-greet to tackle the subject of the nation’s harsh political dialogue. He decried the “politics and point-scoring and pettiness that drifts away with the next news cycle.” “Rather than pointing fingers or assigning blame, let us use this occasion to expand our moral imaginations, to listen to each other more carefully, to sharpen our instincts for empathy, and remind ourselves of all the ways our hopes and dreams are bound together,” Obama told 14,000 people at the University of Arizona’s McKale Memorial Center. Obama did not ascribe a political motive to the alleged shooter or suggest that either party was to blame. Rather, in a 33-minute speech, he sought to move the nation past the tragedy. Accompanied at the arena by first lady Michelle Obama, the president said he joins Tucson in its grief and that he came “as an American who, like all Americans, kneels to pray with you today and will stand by you tomorrow.” After touching down under blue skies and a bright desert sun, Obama paid a surprise visit to victims recovering at University Medical Center, including Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, D-Ariz., whom he joined for nine minutes in the intensive care unit. “Gabby opened her eyes, and I can tell you she knows we are here, she knows we love her and she knows we are rooting for her,” Obama said. Wednesday evening’s hourlong “Together We Thrive: Tucson and America” service was full of spiritual overtones. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano read from the Bible’s book of Isaiah, and Attorney General Eric Holder read from Corinthians. Audience members cheered and hollered throughout the service, at times making it appear more like a rally than a somber memorial. Organizers distributed navy T-shirts to attendees, many of whom snapped pictures of Obama and a litany of dignitaries, including Republican Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer. But the crowd did not lose sight of the purpose. As Giffords’ family entered with three hospital surgeons wearing white lab coats over their scrubs, the crowd stood in applause. Other heroes of the shooting, including Daniel Hernandez, the intern who tended to Giffords at the crime scene, were engulfed in cheers as they were shown on the arena’s video screen. Obama looked gravely serious throughout, pursing his lips even when the crowd screamed in delight. The rampage called for Obama to console weary citizens just as President George W. Bush did after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and President Bill Clinton after the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing. For Obama, it was not the first time he had addressed tragedy and divisiveness. A hallmark of his tenure has been his eagerness to cast himself as a healer. Obama shared personal details he had learned about the six dead: “Our hearts are broken by their sudden passing,” Obama said. “Our hearts are broken — and yet, our hearts also have reason for fullness.” The president said he was grateful for Hernandez, Patricia Maisch and others who ran through chaos at the scene of the massacre to save others. “These men and women remind us that heroism is found not only on the fields of battle,” Obama said. “They remind us that heroism does not require special training or physical strength. Heroism is here, all around us, in the hearts of so many of our fellow citizens, just waiting to be summoned — as it was on Saturday morning.” Obama’s advisers said his remarks were designed to help tamp down the current political conversation. He ruminated about young Christina’s growing interest in her government. As he focused on the child, his wife’s eyes brimmed with tears, and his remarks drew a sustained standing ovation as many in the crowd wept. “She saw all this through the eyes of a child, undimmed by the cynicism or vitriol that we adults all too often just take for granted,” Obama said. “I want us to live up to her expectations. I want our democracy to be as good as (Christina) imagined it. … All of us — we should do everything we can to make sure this country lives up to our children’s expectations. “If there are rain puddles in heaven, Christina is jumping in them today,” he said. “And here on Earth, we place our hands over our hearts, and we commit ourselves as Americans to forging a country that is forever worthy of her gentle, happy spirit.” With the State of the Union address less than two weeks away, Obama’s advisers said it is likely the president will raise the subject again in some manner in the days after the funerals have finished — perhaps in his speech to Congress. title: 9/11 flag unfurled, raised for Arizona girl's funeral
text: Trending:  In this photo provided by the family, Christina Green is shown. Green, 9, was killed at a political event with Rep. Gabrielle Giffords in Tucson, Ariz. on Saturday, Jan. 8, 2011. (AP Photo/Green Family) NO SALES  Firefighters raise the large American flag recovered from Ground Zero after the 9/11 attacks outside the entrance at the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church for the funeral of 9-year-old Christina Taylor Green Thursday, Jan. 13, 2011, in Tucson, Ariz. Green, the youngest victim of Saturday's shooting in Tucson, was born on the day of the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001.  (AP Photo/Mamta Popat, Pool)  TUCSON, AZ - JANUARY 13:  The funeral hearse leads a procession to St. Elizabeth Ann Seton church for the funeral services of nine-year-old Christina Taylor Green on January 13, 2011 in Tucson, Arizona. Green was shot and killed during the January 8, shooting rampage of Jared Lee Loughner during a political event in Tucson. (Photo by David Becker/Getty Images)  Rozanna and John Green, the mother and father of Christina Green, stand with their son Dallas as they arrive for Christina's funeral at the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church on Thursday, Jan. 13, 2011, in Tucson, Ariz. Green was the youngest victim of Saturday's shooting in Tucson. (AP Photo/Mamta Popat, Pool)  TUCSON, AZ - JANUARY 13: Pallbearers escort the casket of nine-year-old Christina Taylor Green into St. Elizabeth Ann Seton church on January 13, 2011 in Tucson, Arizona. Green was shot and killed during the January 8, shooting rampage of Jared Lee Loughner during a political event in Tucson. (Photo by Mamta Popat-Pool/Getty Images)  John Green and son Dallas, the respective father and brother of 9-year-old Christina Green, arrive at the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church for Christina's funeral on Thursday, Jan. 13, 2011, in Tucson, Ariz. Green was the youngest victim of Saturday's shooting in Tucson. (AP Photo/Mamta Popat, Pool)  A hearse arrives at the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church for the funeral of 9-year-old Christina Green Thursday, Jan. 13, 2011, in Tucson, Ariz. Green was the youngest victim of Saturday's shooting in Tucson. (AP Photo/Chris Carlson)  TUCSON, Ariz. — The family of the youngest victim of the mass shooting in Arizona held hands and paused in a moment of silence Thursday under the large American flag recovered from Ground Zero after the 9/11 attacks, and later escorted the 9-year-old’s small brown casket into the church as little girls about her age cried. Several hundred other mourners, many in white T-shirts, lined a road near the church to show support. Christina Taylor Green was born on Sept. 11, 2001, and featured in a book called “Faces of Hope” that chronicled one baby from each state born on the day terrorists killed nearly 3,000 people. Christina’s funeral is the first for the six victims killed when police said a gunman opened fired on a crowd at an event for Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, critically injuring the congresswoman and wounding 13 others. The third-grader had an interest in politics and had recently been elected to her student council. She was the only girl on her Canyon del Oro Little League baseball team and played second base, and had told her father she wanted to become the first woman to play in the major leagues. The game was in her blood. Her dad is a scout for the Los Angeles Dodgers and her grandfather, former big league pitcher Dallas Green, managed the 1980 world champion Philadelphia Phillies. During President Barack Obama’s speech at a memorial Wednesday night, he spoke at length about Christina and reminded the audience that the third-grader’s neighbor had brought her to meet Giffords because of her budding interest in democracy. “She saw all this through the eyes of a child, undimmed by the cynicism or vitriol that we adults all too often just take for granted,” he said. “I want to live up to her expectations. I want our democracy to be as good as Christina imagined it. I want America to be as good as she imagined it.” The girl had told her parents she wanted to attend Penn State and have a career that involved helping those less fortunate. Before her funeral, cars were parked on both sides of the road, and traffic was backed up. Members of motorcycle groups from Arizona and California parked their bikes in a group. Several hundred people, many dressed in white T-shirts, stood silently along a road near the church. About 20 people were dressed as angels. They organized over the Internet and by word of mouth, saying they wanted to be there in case members of a Kansas church showed up to protest. The Westboro Baptist Church threatened to picket the funerals for Christina and other victims, but they backed off, in part because a nationally syndicated radio show agreed to host some of their members. The church is known for protesting at the funerals of slain servicemen and blaming their deaths on the country’s tolerance of homosexuality. As the city mourned the little girl, more details and documents surfaced about the suspect, Jared Loughner. For four years, he was an unremarkable college student, commuting to classes near his home where he studied yoga and algebra, business management and poetry. But last year, his classroom conduct began to change. In February, Loughner stunned a teacher by talking about blowing up babies, a bizarre outburst that marked the start of a rapid unraveling for the 22-year-old. After his first flare-up, campus police decided not to intervene. “I suggested they keep an eye on him,” an officer wrote. Loughner’s on-campus behavior grew increasingly erratic, menacing, even delusional. Fifty-one pages of police reports released Wednesday provided a chilling portrait of Loughner’s last school year, which ended in September when he was judged mentally unhinged and suspended by Pima Community College. New details were also still emerging about the busy morning Loughner had in the hours before the shooting. According to authorities, Loughner hustled to Walmart twice, was caught by police running a red light but was let go with a warning, and later grabbed a black bag from the trunk of a family car before fleeing into the desert on foot with his suspicious father giving chase. Eventually, he took a cab to the grocery store where he opened fire on Giffords and a line of people waiting to speak to her. Loughner was also carrying a knife but didn’t use it. Also Thursday, a man walking his dog found a black bag holding ammunition and authorities believed it was discarded by Loughner. Chief Rick Kastigar with the Pima County Sheriff’s Office told The Associated Press that an 18-year-old found the bag in a neighborhood near where Loughner lives. He went to get another man, who looked inside and saw ammunition. Just three months before the shooting, Loughner had been kicked out of school. In a Sept. 23 campus police report, days before his suspension, an officer called to quiet another one of Loughner’s outbursts described him as incomprehensible, his eyes jittery, his head awkwardly tilted. “He very slowly began telling me in a low and mumbled voice that under the Constitution, which had been written on the wall for all to see, he had the right to his ‘freedom of thought’ and whatever he thought in his head he could also put on paper. … His teacher ‘must be required to accept it’ as a passing grade,” the officer wrote. “It was clear he was unable to fully understand his actions.” During his first outburst, in a poetry class, he made comments about abortion, wars and killing people, then asked: “Why don’t we just strap bombs to babies?” Later, he became hostile with a Pilates instructor when he learned he was going to receive a B in the class. According to school officials, Loughner studied at the college from the summer of 2005 to September, when he was suspended after campus police discovered a YouTube video in which Loughner claimed the college was illegal under to the U.S. Constitution. In all, he had five run-ins with police on two campuses. Loughner was warned that the behavior had to stop. On Nov. 30, the same day he bought the Glock, Loughner posted a YouTube video, seething about campus police and the college. “If the police remove you from the educational facility for talking then removing you from the educational facility for talking is unconstitutional,” he said on the video. “The situation is fraud because the police are unconstitutional. … Every Pima Community College class is always a scam!” School officials told Loughner and his parents that to return to classes he would need to undergo a mental health exam to show he was not a danger. He never returned. Kelsey Hawkes said Thursday on CBS’ “The Early Show” that when she dated Loughner six years ago when they were both in high school, he showed no violent tendencies and he was a completely different person. “Very caring, very sweet, a gentle, kind, you know, a little bit quiet. But altogether a pretty great guy,” she said. Associated Press writers Amanda Lee Myers, Alicia Chang and Gillian Flaccus in Tucson, and Jacques Billeaud and Bob Christie in Phoenix contributed to this report. title: Tucson battles Wild West image
Hundreds come out for  youngest  rampage victim's funeral
text: Thanks for contacting us. We've received your submission. TUCSON, Ariz.  — Christina Taylor Green, whose nine exuberant years began and ended with two of the most harrowing tragedies in recent American history, was laid to rest Thursday, her life cut short in a hail of bullets at a Tucson shopping center but her spirit remembered as fun-filled and loving. At a service that mixed “Ave Maria” with Billy Joel and ended with the plaintive wail of a bagpiper playing “Amazing Grace,” Bishop Gerald F. Kicanas told the 1,800 mourners inside the church that Christina “wanted to make a difference with her life, to make her mark. She has done so in such a powerful way that even she could not have imagined.” COPS FIND BAG WITH AMMO NEAR ‘SHOOTER’S’ HOME DOCTORS PURSUE AGGRESSIVE THERAPY WITH GIFFORDS SEN. GILLIBRAND DESCRIBES SEEING GIFFORDS OPEN EYES DEVOTED HUSBAND IS A ‘ROCK’ OF COMFORT AND COURAGE He also cited the many “times” of her life — “she had a time to laugh, a time to dance, which she so loved, a time to live and a time to build. She had a time to outshine the boys in baseball…a time to hug her little black stuffed dog, to love animals, to swim with her brother Dallas, which she so enjoyed, to model and be in fashion, to be elected to the Student Council, to be a leader and represent her class.” At the end of the service the Bishop also told the mourners, who included a number of Christina’s elementary school classmates and fellow Little League team members, that she had been an organ donor. The only other speaker was Christina’s father, John, who spoke directly to his daughter and said, “I think you’ve affected the whole country.” Outside the pink stone St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Catholic Church, a mammoth US flag that survived the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center – the day of Christina’s birth– fluttered between the ladders of two Tucson Fire Department trucks. As her family – her father, mother Roxanna and 11-year-old brother, Dallas – arrived for the service, they paused to look up at the flag under the crystal blue sky, gently rubbing each other’s shoulders. Then, all holding hands, they slowly walked beneath it and into the church, followed by other family members. Minutes later, the hearse carrying Christina’s child-size coffin, reportedly made of red oak especially for her by Trappist monks in Iowa, pulled up in front of the flag. Her parents and brother re-emerged to accompany her as a family for one of the last times as the coffin was wheeled inside. GAL PUT LOUGHNER ON PATH TO MADNESS HILLARY TAKES NIGHTMARE TO NEW EXTREME NEW YORKERS RUSH TO BUY GUNS VIDEO: ‘SHE OPENED HER EYES’ No television cameras were allowed inside the church for the nearly 90-minute funeral Mass. Afterwards, the family again walked with Christina to the hearse, this time with young Dallas placing his hand on his sister’s coffin. Christina, a brown-haired third grader, was the youngest victim of a shooting rampage Saturday outside a Tucson supermarket that gravely wounded Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords (D-Ariz.) and killed six others. Jared Lee Loughner, a troubled 22-year-old loner, has been charged in the deaths. Among the mourners at Christina’s funeral was Mark Kelly, Giffords’ husband and a NASA astronaut, along with her sister, Melissa. Also present were Arizona’s two Republican senators, John McCain and Jon Kyl. After her death, from a gunshot wound to the chest, Christina was remembered as a spirited “Princess” – her father’s nickname for her – who had a kaleidoscope of interests including ballet, baseball (she was the only girl on an all boys team, the Pirates), swimming and politics. She went to the shopping center that day with a neighbor specifically to see Giffords because she had recently been elected to the Student Council at her elementary school and wanted to learn more. “She was very interested in politics since she was a little girl,” her mother told ABC. “I think that being born on 9/11 had a lot to do with that.” In fact, she appeared in a book “Faces of Hope” featuring a child from each state born on Sept. 11, 2001. Sports talent ran deep in her family. Christina was the granddaughter of Dallas Green, who managed the Philadelphia Phillies, New York Yankees and New York Mets. Her father is a supervising scout for the Los Angeles Dodgers. And aside from her not surprising prowess at baseball, Christina was also a gymnast and a swimmer. But, her mother said, “she was a girly girl as well as a tomboy.” The Arizona Republic reported she had a dollhouse, a boom box and an Audrey Hepburn poster in her bedroom. And this handwritten sign on her bedroom door: “Girls only. Back off boys. Girls rock.” Share Selection
